issue.title: In Python, I've defined a custom factor but I'm unsure how to compute the Jacobian matrix. Can GTSAM automatically handle differentiation? Are there relevant interfaces for this?
issue.body:
> You create a custom function that computes `z-f(x)`. Then, in the `evaluateError` function of your customized factor, you can call the `numericalDerivative` function to compute the Jacobian numerically. Examples in `testNumericalDerivative.cpp` will help you get familiar with the function. 

@yetongumich 
Hello, may I ask if it's possible to automatically solve for the Jacobian using GTSAM if I'm implementing a custom factor in Python, where I only know the error function and am not familiar with how to perform the Jacobian calculation? Are there relevant interfaces for this in GTSAM?

_Originally posted by @goodgoodliving in https://github.com/borglab/gtsam/issues/1547#issuecomment-1782173621_

issue.title: Custom factor without Jacobian
issue.body: Hi, I want to create a custom factor but I am not sure how to get the analytic Jacobian. Can I just create the factor with the error formula z - f(x) and let gtsam calculate the Jacobian numerically?

comment.body:
> You create a custom function that computes `z-f(x)`. Then, in the `evaluateError` function of your customized factor, you can call the `numericalDerivative` function to compute the Jacobian numerically. Examples in `testNumericalDerivative.cpp` will help you get familiar with the function.

Hello, may I ask if it's possible to automatically solve for the Jacobian using GTSAM if I'm implementing a custom factor in Python, where I only know the error function and am not familiar with how to perform the Jacobian calculation? Are there relevant interfaces for this in GTSAM?

issue.title: Pose2 theta coordinate convention
issue.body:
Hello, I'm a new user to building pose graphs using this library and would like some help to understand the coordinate convention of Pose2. The documentation [here](https://gtsam.org/doxygen/4.0.0/a02687.html) says that theta is the "angle with the positive x axis", which I believe is x to the right and y pointing forward. The [ROS convention](https://www.ros.org/reps/rep-0103.html) is shifted by 90 degrees such that x is pointing forward and y is to the left. I did a few calculations by hand and figured out that the value of theta should still be the same regardless of the frames, however when I feed in the yaw values that I'm receiving from my visual odometry measurements (in ROS convention), my pose graph diverges as such. Does anyone have any insight into this?
![Figure_1](https://github.com/borglab/gtsam/assets/86030027/fcb67420-a9e4-4211-9ace-d3266d246cdb)

issue.title: Difference between Analytical and Numerical Jacobian for BetweenFactor
Difference between Analytical and Numerical Jacobian for BetweenFactor

comment.body:
It seems like the multiplication from left with the right jacobian is exactly the missing bit left away for efficiency reasons and which can be enabled by compiling with `GTSAM_SLOW_BUT_CORRECT_BETWEENFACTOR`:

https://github.com/borglab/gtsam/blob/b5d19fb446c1bb7e04b06a1a1d5e73d9ea8a525c/gtsam/slam/BetweenFactor.h#L115

payload.description: GTSAM is a library of C++ classes that implement smoothing and mapping (SAM) in robotics and vision, using factor graphs and Bayes networks as the underlying computing paradigm rather than sparse matrices.

pull_request.title: Chebyshev2 Improvements
pull_request.body:
According to Trefethen, given N, we should form a polynomial with N+1 nodes, but we form a polynomial with N nodes (which is mathematically a N-1 degree polynomial).

Hence one of the bigger changes of this PR is to form a polynomial over N+1 nodes. This makes our code correspond directly to the math and makes comparison to Chebfun much easier.

Additionally, I've tightened some bounds checks and improved the overall API.
